docs.lead_paragraph: Two 30-second television commercials, titled ''Imagine'' and ''Who You Fight For,'' were released yesterday by James E. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, in his campaign for governor of New Jersey. He is unopposed in the Democratic primary, but since he is free to spend up to $5.9 million, he is placing self-promotional ads. These are to run on broadcast stations in New York and Philadelphia at a cost of $1.9 million until the June 26 election. PRODUCERS -- Greer, Margolis, Mitchell, Burns & Associates Inc.; Message & Media

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The headline of a June 4 editorial reads ''Confusion on Affirmative Action,'' but there should be no confusion. Racial preferences are anathema. The people of California and Washington State affirmed this when they voted to prohibit discrimination. In education, the issue boils down to diversity versus the Constitution. Do universities have the right to infringe on a citizen's right to equal protection under the law in order to achieve racial diversity?

headline.main: Ways to Define A Diverse Campus

docs.abstract: Ellen Rautenberg, president of Medical and Health Research Assn, letter lauds New York State Gov George Pataki's action in providing health insurance for working poor; says that state, however, needs to cover cost of providing prenatal care to all low income New Yorkers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Mr. Pataki Broadens Health Insurance'' (editorial, June 4): New Yorkers should hail Gov. George E. Pataki's action in providing insurance for the working poor and also the recent ruling by the State Court of Appeals declaring that the state's denial of Medicaid coverage to qualified immigrants is unconstitutional. However, a decision last month by a federal appeals court will leave one of the state's neediest groups with no coverage for prenatal care: undocumented, pregnant immigrant women.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, Gov. George E. Pataki has been one of New York's most familiar salesmen, pitching everything from New York tourism to children's health insurance to energy-saving appliances, in television ads paid for with tens of millions of dollars in state funds. But Mr. Pataki was not always so fond of such advertisements. As an assemblyman, he voted to ban the use of public money for any ads that featured statewide elected officials.

headline.main: Pataki's Role as a Pitchman Becomes a Political Target

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki's frequent appearance in state-funded ads for everything from New York tourism to children's health insurance to energy-saving appliances is attacked by two Democrats running to unseat him, Comptroller H Carl McCall and Andrew M Cuomo, who recall that in 1990, when Pataki was assemblyman, he voted for budget amendment that would have made it illegal for state money to go toward ads featuring officials elected statewide and later voted for budget amendment that would have eliminated most public-relations budgets of state agencies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An appeals court has barred Vermont from offering reduced drug prices under a state program, saying a federal agency acted improperly when it approved the program. Under the program, the state offered enrollees discounts of up to 30 percent, then required pharmaceutical companies to make up the difference. The Vermont plan had been approved by the federal Health and Human Services Department.

headline.main: Court Rejects Drug Discounts For Vermonters

docs.abstract: Appeals court bars Vermont from offering reduced drug prices under state program, saying federal Health and Human Services Dept acted improperly when it approved program; under program, state offers senior citizen enrollees discounts of up to 30 percent, then requires pharmaceutical companies to make up difference; trade group representing pharmaceutical industry challenged program (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the new majority leader, pledged today that Democrats would not engage in ''payback'' for the way Republicans stalled the confirmation of judges during the Clinton administration, saying, ''We have to break the cycle.'' At a Capitol news conference, Mr. Daschle gave his assurance that most of President Bush's nominees would get ''a fair chance'' for Senate consideration. He spoke as negotiations continued between the parties over how to reorganize committees in a Senate now under Democratic control. The handling of judicial nominees is the most sensitive issue in the talks.

headline.main: Daschle Says Most Nominees Will Get a Senate Vote

docs.abstract: New Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, pledges Democrats will not engage in 'payback' for way Republicans stalled confirmation of judges during Clinton administration; says Democrats will insist on maintaining Senate practice in which senators from home state of judicial nominee are consulted and can block candidacy; pledge apparently clears way for deal to give Democrats one-seat edge on all Senate committees; Daschle warns Bush administration he sees no room for compromise on patients' bill of rights, first bill Democrats plan to bring to Senate floor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office provided the first independent estimates today of the cost of new Medicare drug benefits, showing that the proposals of Senate Democrats and House Republicans are both affordable under the budget adopted by Congress earlier this year. Members of both parties welcomed the estimates and said they increased the likelihood of legislative action on the issue this year.

headline.main: Rival Medicare Drug Plans Are Both Ruled Affordable

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office estimates cost of Medicare drug benefits proposed by Senate Democrats at $318 billion over decade, slightly above $300 million maximum set by budget; puts cost of plan backed by House Republicans at $157 billion over decade; says approach favored by Senate Republicans that would offer drug benefits through range of competing health plans would cost $176 billion; warns Medicare coverage would spur drug demand, boosting prices (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Each year, Gov. George E. Pataki has a goal in mind for the Medicaid budget: lower it. Yet this year it seems that with every month that passes, that budget is pushed in the opposite direction, and there is little the governor can do about it. Sometimes it is because of political pressures, as was the case last spring when union and hospital leaders begged him to sign on to a public health insurance program for the working poor and to hold the line on Medicaid cuts to hospitals.

headline.main: Rulings on Medicaid for Immigrants Step Up the Pressure on Albany

docs.abstract: News Analysis on court ruling that New York violated state and federal Constitutions by denying Medicaid benefits to legal immigrants who arrived after 1996, and now must pay; Gov George Pataki says he will comply with ruling but may have trouble finding dollars; Medicaid is largest component of state budget, which is now two months overdue; says there is no one Pataki can afford to alienate and there is no place Medicaid budget can be cut, and so he anticipates going to federal government for help (M)
docs.snippet: Each year, Gov. George E. Pataki has a goal in mind for the Medicaid budget: lower it. Yet this year it seems that with every month that passes, that budget is pushed in the opposite direction, and there is little the governor can do about it.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: ANY politicians who unexpectedly walk away from high office usually find their stated motives met with suspicion if not outright disbelief. More time with the family? Right. Looking for new challenges? Sure. But when Lt. Gov. Bill Ratliff surprised the Texas political world this week by announcing that he would step away from the job considered the most powerful in state government rather than fight to retain it in the elections next year, his explanation seemed strangely believable, and sobering. A Republican known for his candor and willingness to treat bipartisanship as something more than a useful sound bite, Mr. Ratliff said he loved policy and public service but hated politics.

headline.main: A Power in Texas Governing Finds Fault in Texas Politics

docs.abstract: Public Lives interview with Lt Gov Bill Ratliff on his decision not to seek election to full term; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Electronic Data Systems, the second-largest computer-services company in the nation, has agreed to pay Texas $3.91 million after the state accused the company of overcharging by millions of dollars to process Medicaid claims. Electronic Data will refund the state $3.43 million and pay a $250,000 penalty and $232,000 to cover Texas's investigation costs, a company spokesman, Ken Smalling, said. Electronic Data did not admit wrongdoing. Charges will not be filed against Electronic Data or National Heritage Insurance, the Electronic Data unit that handles Medicaid claims processing, the district attorney's office in Travis County, Tex., said.

headline.main: ELECTRONIC DATA TO PAY $3.91 MILLION IN MEDICAID DISPUTE

docs.abstract: Electronic Data Systems agrees to pay Texas $3.91 million after state accused it of overcharging to process Medicaid claims (S)
